seo.metaTitle: NWA Daily - A daily newsletter about all things Northwest Arkansas
seo.metaDescription: NWA Daily is a daily email newsletter that keeps readers up to date on the latest Northwest Arkansas news or NWA news in events, restaurants, business,  the community, politics, art, entertainment, culture, and sports in Northwest Arkansas including news about Bentonville, Rogers, Springdale, and Fayetteville

posts.title: Arkansas Gymnastics Tumbling Into 2023 With Enthusiasm
posts.content:
Arkansas Gymnastics has ten regular season meets on deck for 2023, giving Northwest Arkansas an excellent opportunity for family fun and entertainment for all ages.

  • At home: This season's schedule has the University of Arkansas hosting five home meets this spring, three in Barnhill Arena and two in Bud Walton Arena.
  • Make history: Last season, the Gymbacks made history with the first-ever gymnastics meet at the venue against Auburn and set a new single-meet attendance record with 10,345 fans in the building.

Season tickets start at $25! Get yours HERE.

posts.title: Springdale Florist Designed Sarah Huckabee Sanders' Inaugural Ball
posts.content:
Glenn Schnetzinger, owner of Organic Creations in Springdale, was chosen to design the floral decorations for Governor-elect Sarah Huckabee Sanders' inauguration.

  • Blossoming: Schnetzinger is one of the few designers in Arkansas to be inducted into the American Institute of Floral Design, studied under the prestigious Gregor Lersch, and has been featured in the Dallas Museum of Art, Crystal Bridges, and numerous design publications.
  • Famous flowers: Designing Governor-elect Sanders' inauguration adds to Schnetzinger's repertoire of renowned events, having been part of design teams for four Academy Awards ceremonies and President Bush's inauguration in 2001.

Read more on the story HERE.

posts.title: Boulevard Bread Company Coming To Fayetteville
posts.content:
Boulevard Bread Company of Little Rock announced plans for a location on Crossover Rd in Fayetteville with hopes to open this spring.

  • On the rise: Founded in 1999, the company has three locations in Little Rock. Co-owners Johnathan Buford and Joshua Begley will operate the Fayetteville location.
  • Same favorites: Christina McGehee, co-owner of the Little Rock restaurants, told the Fayetteville Flyer that the new location plans to offer the same menu, including their beloved pastries, fresh bread, sandwiches, soup, coffee, and more.

Check out the story in the Fayetteville Flyer HERE.

posts.title: Local Chef Serving The Community A Second Helping Of Care
posts.content:
KUAF's Ozarks at Large invited local chef Nate Walls onto the show to hear his story of founding Second Helping NWA and how he's using barbecue as a force for good in the community.

  • Smokin': Nate Walls is the owner of Secondhand Smoke NWA, sharing the skills he cultivated as a chef during his years in the Army by whipping up some killer barbecue and comfort food.
  • Servin': When the pandemic hit, he couldn't sit idly by while many in the community went hungry, and what started as cooking meals for neighbors in need transformed into the nonprofit Second Helpings NWA, which has served nearly 8,000 meals.

Start the day with a few laughs and feel inspired by listening HERE.

posts.title: Willow Creek Women's Hospital Receives Excellence Award
posts.content:
Press Ganey recognized Willow Creek Women's Hospital in Johnson as a 2022 Human Experience Guardian of Excellence Award for their performance in physician engagement.

  • For the girls: Dedicated exclusively to women's health needs, Willow Creek is a full-service facility that offers a range of services, including obstetrics, breast imaging, an OB/GYN emergency department, and a Level Illa NICU.
  • Trophy case: Before this award, Willow Creek was the first Arkansas hospital to be recognized as a baby-friendly birth facility, the first in the nation to earn VBAC Center of Excellence status, and is one of the few recipients of the Governor's Award for Performance Excellence.

Read the full story HERE.

posts.title: Stone Mill Bread Announces Fayetteville Location Will Reopen
posts.content:
Fayetteville, wipe your tears! Like a phoenix reborn, Stone Mill Bread will return to its flagship location on Gregg Ave after completing a remodel.

  • It's not goodbye: The local-favorite bakery and cafe closed unexpectedly in October 2022, citing long-term lease negotiations as the reason and devastating the city's sandwich lovers.
  • Meanwhile: The completion date of the remodel is currently unknown, but in the meantime, Stone Mill-Super Fans of Fayetteville can make the drive up to their other locations in Springdale and Bentonville.

Stay tuned for updates HERE.

posts.title: Razorback Stadium Named 2022 College Football Field Of The Year
posts.content:
Donald W. Reynolds Razorback Stadium and Frank Broyles Field have been recognized as the 2022 College Football Stadium of the Year by the Sports Field Management Association.

  • Nice grass: Jeff Foor, the Director of Sports Turf Operations for the Razorbacks, and his team received the honor from the SFMA, a worldwide organization of over 2,500 members who manage sports fields.
  • Back to life: Recognition is due for the team's impressive expertise and hard work in revitalizing the turfgrass in time for the 2022 football season after the entire field had to be covered for a Garth Brooks concert and a Top Golf event last spring.

Read more on the story HERE.

posts.title: Software Developer Metova Moving Headquarters To Ledger In Bentonville
posts.content:
The community forming at Ledger gained a new neighbor as software development company Metova relocates its headquarters from Franklin, TN, to Bentonville after a change in ownership.

  • New horizons: Having been recently acquired from a private equity firm by the current management team, Metova is focused on providing software solutions in industries like healthcare, retail, consumer services, and entertainment.
  • Community add: The move to Bentonville will establish Metova as a leading company in Arkansas's growing tech industry and position it to partner well with local businesses and the Northwest Arkansas community.

Read more from Talk Business & Politics HERE.

posts.title: Weekend Roundup
posts.content:
We're here to help you enjoy your first weekend of 2023!

  • Go girls: Break out the mountain bikes with Women of OZ for their January Flagship Ride on Saturday, Jan 7, at 2p.
  • Howdy farmer: Check out the first of the winter markets by the Fayetteville Farmers' Market this Saturday, Jan 7, from 11a-3p at the Fayetteville Senior Center.
  • Bring your mom: Listen to the beautiful sounds of the Symphony of Northwest Arkansas on Saturday, Jan 7, at 7:30p for their performance: Mother and Child.
  • Pickleball: Swing your paddles in the Pickleball Up and Down the River event at JBU in Siloam Springs on Saturday, Jan 7, from 6-8p.
  • For the record: Shop, eat food, and enjoy fun activities at the Market @ Record in Bentonville on Saturday, Jan 7, from 9a-12p.
  • Do the twist: See snowboarder Shaun White and other athletes perform amazing flips and twists outside the Walmart on Pleasant Crossing in Rogers on Sunday, Jan 8.
  • It could be worse: Don't miss the last weekend of the immersive, STEM-based exhibition "Worst-Case Scenario Survival Experience" at The Jones Center, ending on Jan 12.

Have a great weekend! We'll be back Monday.

posts.title: Gravette Seeks Public Input For Comprehensive Plan
posts.content:
In partnership with Northwest Arkansas Regional Planning, Gravette is working on an update for the city's comprehensive plan, which directs the growth and development of the town.

  • Future vision: The policies outlined in the plan will guide the decisions of the Planning Commission and City Council in the coming years, and the city wants your feedback to set the vision in line with the citizens' wants/needs.
  • Present survey: The survey covers various topics like the quality of life, infrastructure, and the I-49 bypass.

Add your voice to the survey HERE.

posts.title: Shaun White Visits Rogers For Fiesta Twists 360º Event
posts.content:
Ever imagine you'd see legendary snowboarder Shaun White throw a Double McTwist 1260... in front of a Walmart...in Arkansas? We didn't either, but there's a chance you might this Sunday, Jan 8, at the Pleasant Crossing Walmart in Rogers.

  • Stunts and snacks: Each time slot includes a showing of snowboarders performing epic stunts, athletes doing extreme trampoline flips, and a chance to sample Old El Paso's new Fiesta Twists.
  • Full 360º: Walmart+ Members can bring up to three guests, and the first 200 Walmart+ members have a chance to sign up for a meet and greet with Shaun White.

Learn more about the event and reserve a spot HERE.

posts.title: Recent U of A Grad Buys Uncle Sam's Safari Outfitters In Fayetteville
posts.content:
When Justin Macedo started a consulting project for Uncle Sam's Safari Outfitters as part of an assignment in his small business class, he never imagined he'd soon become the owner of one of Fayetteville's oldest outdoor gear and clothing stores.

  • Opportunity: Macedo worked for the store's previous owner, Ryland Arnold, and while completing his entrepreneurship project, he learned Arnold was actually interested in selling the business. So he jumped at the opportunity.
  • Iconic: Uncle Sam's was first opened in 1982 by Robert Ginsburg in a backroom off Dickson St and later relocated to Evelyn Hills Shopping Center in 1985.

Read more on the story from Talk Business & Politics HERE.

posts.title: The Spark Foundation Running For Personal And Community Health
posts.content:
The Spark Foundation is here to help you reach all your health and fitness resolutions this year by helping you set achievable goals with their free resources and race opportunities.

  • On your mark: Give yourself a finish line to run towards by signing up for one of The Spark Foundation's races this year. Races are planned throughout Northwest Arkansas in partnership with other local organizations.
  • Run for good: All money raised by the Spark Foundation races goes back into the community through physical education programs, after-school run clubs, playground equipment improvements, and other organizations that support healthy lifestyles.

Find more ways to get involved HERE.

posts.title: Free Pizza At Grand Opening Of Smokin' Oak Wood-Fired Pizza & Taproom
posts.content:
With a menu full of fresh, artisan-quality items and wood-fired pizzas baked in a custom oven, our mouths are already watering for the Grand Opening of Smokin' Oak Wood-fired Pizza & Taproom this Sunday, Jan. 8, from 12-7p.

  • Celebrate with Free Pizza: Come to the Grand Opening and receive a free individual-sized pizza while supplies last. The full menu will also be available for purchase, along with the digital taproom.
  • Taproom. Taste. Repeat.: Smokin' Oak Pizza & Taproom offers a unique digital taproom wall. The Taproom offers a rotating selection of craft and domestic beers, wines, and mixed cocktails.

Check out the menu and learn more HERE.

posts.title: SoNA Continues Season With "Mother And Child" Performance This Weekend
posts.content:
Let the Symphony of Northwest Arkansas pull all your heartstrings this Saturday, Jan 7, at 7:30p in a performance that explores the love that exists across time between a Mother and Child.

  • Be still my heart: Experience the joyous notes of the show's namesake piece, Mother and Child, composed by William Grant Still, the first African American composer to be performed by a major symphony orchestra and heralded as the "Dean of African American Composers."
  • A mother's cry: The SoNA Singers will lend their voices to Leonard Bernstein's popular choral work, Chichester Psalms, and the haunting sounds of Henryk Górecki’s Symphony of Sorrows will be performed with help from award-winning soprano Miriam Khalil.

Get your tickets HERE before this becomes SoNA's fourth sold-out performance in a row!

posts.title: Northwest Arkansas Projected As A Top 10 Real Estate Market For 2023
posts.content:
The National Association of Realtors projected the Northwest Arkansas metro at #4 on their top ten list of real estate markets to watch in 2023.

  • On the rise: The information industry in Northwest Arkansas rose at twice the rate of the nationwide average in 2022. As an emerging tech hub that has remained relatively affordable, the real estate market will likely hold steady if not continue to rise.
  • Measurables: NAR determined its top 10 list based on various indicators, including housing affordability, the number of renters capable of affording median-priced homes, job and population growth, and other metrics.

Read the full report HERE.

posts.title: Medical Device Company In Fayetteville Receives $1.25m In Series A Funding
posts.content:
Lapovations, a medical device company out of Fayetteville, raised $1.25m in Series A funding, exceeding their $1m goal by 25% thanks to eager investors.

  • Ab day: Lapovation's flagship product is the AbGrab, an innovative device designed to lift the abdominal wall during laparoscopic surgeries, making the procedure less invasive and reducing complications.
  • Fifty-pack: AbGrab officially launched in October 2022, and the company has since expanded across eight states with a sales team of 50 representatives and plans to add at least 75 more within the year.

Read more on Talk Business & Politics HERE.

posts.title: The Fayetteville Farmers' Market Kicks Off Winter Markets Series
posts.content:
The farmers may be cozied up for the winter, but the market is still open! The Fayetteville Farmers' Market begins its winter markets series this weekend, and as usual, you can shop vendors online for curbside pickup.

  • Inside: Indoor Saturday Markets at the Fayetteville Senior Center take place each weekend, Jan 7 - Mar 11, from 11a-3p, offering seasonal produce, baked goods, handcrafted items, and more.
  • Online: Orders placed on the Online Market each week between Sunday 6p and Wednesday 6a can be picked up curbside at the Fayetteville Public Library each Thursday from 4:30-5:30p.

Find more details in the Fayetteville Flyer HERE.

posts.title: Northwest Arkansas MLK Council Hosts 27th Annual Recommitment Celebration
posts.content:
The Northwest Arkansas Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Council invites the public to the 27th Annual MLK Recommitment Celebration at the Fayetteville Public Library on Saturday, Jan 14, from 5-9p.

  • Recognition: Enjoy dynamic local entertainment and celebrate the recipients of the 2023 Salute to Greatness Award along with high school and college scholarship recipients.
  • Dreamkeepers: Focusing on the theme of Disruptive Love: The Foundation of the Beloved Community, the event will feature an intimate conversation with one of America's leading thinkers, Dr. Cornel West.

Purchase tickets for the event HERE.

posts.title: Butterfield Trail Pending Recognition As National Historic Trail
posts.content:
A bill authored by Sen. John Boozman that would designate Butterfield Overland Trail as a National Historic Trail is awaiting President Biden's signature to make it final.

  • Westward: At approximately 3,553 miles, Butterfield Trail was the longest stagecoach operation in world history and was used to transport passengers and mail between St. Louis, Memphis, and San Fransisco.
  • Snail mail: The Butterfield Overland Mail Company operated the trail from 1858-1861, and Northwest Arkansas was home to numerous important stops along the way, most notably Fitzgerald Station, which still stands in Springdale.

Find an interactive map of historic stops along the trail HERE.

posts.title: Fay Jones Inspired Medians For College Ave Project Earn Support From City's Arts Council
posts.content:
Fayetteville's Arts Council had positive reviews for preliminary drawings of Fay Jones-inspired medians to be built as part of the city's 71B Corridor Plan.

  • Glow up: The project intends to improve car traffic, create safer pedestrian and bicycle pathways, add bus shelters and transit lanes, and improve the overall look of College Ave between North St and Joyce Blvd.
  • The Fay-vorite: RDG Planning & Design presented options for the plan's decorative medians, and the Arts Council favored the Fay Jones theme, paying homage to the Arkansas-native architect who apprenticed under Frank Lloyd Wright.

Read more from Northwest Arkansas Democrat-Gazette HERE.

posts.title: Empowering Veterans By Journeying The Warrior PATHH
posts.content:
Sheep Dog Impact Assistance was founded in Rogers in 2010 to help our nation’s veterans and first responders by engaging them in programs like Outdoor Adventures, Continued Service/Disaster Response, and Warrior PATHH Training.

  • Struggle to strength: An acronym for Progressive and Alternative Training for Helping Heroes, Warrior PATHH is the nation’s ﬁrst non-clinical, peer-to-peer program designed to equip veterans and first responders to transform their past trauma and experiences into post-traumatic growth.
  • Results: The program began in March 2021 with the help of some of the nation’s leading psychologists and therapists specializing in post-traumatic stress disorder.

Read more from Arkansas Money & Politics HERE.

posts.title: Start Your Sustainable Journey in 2023 With Ozark Compost
posts.content:
Ozark Compost & Swap has diverted over 50,000 lbs of waste from local landfills by offering compost pickup and zero-waste product delivery services to Northwest Arkansas. 

  • Convenient composting: With easy-to-follow compost guides, seven-day customer support, and text notifications, composting could not be easier. Fill up your 5-gal bucket with compostable items and OCS will pick it up and swap it for a clean one on a weekly or bi-weekly basis. 
  • Conscious consumption: Include a subscription for ground or whole-bean Airship coffee with your deliveries, and find eco-friendly, zero-waste products on Ozark Compost's online shop.

The first 50 NWA Daily readers to sign up will receive a free month of bi-weekly pickups and a free refillable coffee canister when you add a coffee subscription using the code OCS2023 or by clicking HERE.

posts.title: 8th & Walton Of Bentonville Earns B-Corp Status
posts.content:
The Bentonville-based firm 8th & Walton was issued a B-Corp certification in recognition of its efforts to be a business force for good, making it the second Arkansas-based company to receive B-Corp status.

  • B good: The certification is issued by B Lab, a nonprofit out of Pennsylvania that evaluates businesses' compliance with social and environmental standards such as social impact, financial transparency, and legal accountability.
  • Empowered: 8th & Walton provides suppliers with classes, Retail Link training, and other customized services to help them become better partners with Walmart and increase the world's access to healthy, affordable, sustainable products.

Read the full Talk Business & Politics story HERE.

node.content:
Northwest Arkansas is leading the state in many ways with its active plans for clean energy, its elevating tech scene, its strong foothold in advanced air mobility, and its mountain biking infrastructure. Among the array of reasons NWA is a great place to be, the region is also making moves to be known for its approach to holistic health. 

Photo courtesy of Andrea Piacquadio

Already, institutions like the University of Health and Performance, the Children's Safety Center, and the Whole Health Institute create environments where the priority and emphasis are on the health of the whole person. The region's latest endeavor to make NWA an epicenter of holistic health is the Alice L. Walton School of Medicine, which is working to combine conventional medicine with integrative techniques and principles. Emotional and mental health is top of mind right now for many people and is an essential part of the well-rounded nature of a healthy community. 

Photo courtesy of Tirachard Kumtanom

While new initiatives are happening, there are already several organizations in NWA for counseling and therapy of all kinds. One of the hardest things sometimes, we think, is how many options there are. So the team at NWA Daily has done some research to narrow down 13 counseling options in the region to create a resource for your mental and emotional health journey.

Photo courtesy of Alex Green

In order by location:

1. Psychology and Counseling Associates

1 W. Sunbridge Dr., Fayetteville

5434 W Walsh Ln., Rogers

Psychology and Counseling Associates has been voted Best Mental Health Clinic for 10 years in a row. It has an office in Fayetteville and Rogers and offers services for ADHD/Learning Difficulties, Alcohol Use Disorder, Anxiety, Depression, Marital Therapy, PTSD, Sexual Health, Eating Disorders, and more. 

Fayetteville: 479.443.5575

Rogers: 479.442.2311

2. Talk Center Counseling Services

130 N College Ave, Fayetteville

Talk Center Counseling strives to help people find their sense of wholeness. Their licensed professional counselors and social service workers serve adults, families, teens, and children. Talk Center Counseling also offers group therapy for teenage girls and a yoga group for those suffering from anxiety.

479.396.8806

3. The Joshua Center

3680 N. Investment Dr, Fayetteville

2105 S. 54th St, Rogers

920 S. Caroline St, Siloam Springs

The Joshua Center offers individual adult therapy, therapy for children, adolescents, and families, couples therapy, pre-marital counseling, and discernment work. The center utilizes different approaches such as emotionally-focused therapy, play therapy, EMDR, brain spotting, and others. 

Fayetteville: 479.435.9356

Rogers: 479.268.4557

Siloam Springs: 479.373.2377

4. Midtown Counseling

1845 Green Acres Rd, Fayetteville

 Midtown Counseling provides counseling services and specialized evaluations to individuals, families, and groups. They accept most major insurance providers and are certified by the Arkansas Board of Examiners in Counseling, the National Board of Certified Counselors, and the American Counseling Association.

479.957.8546

Photo courtesy of cottonbro

5. Pinnacle Counseling 

5500 W Pinnacle Pointe Dr, Rogers

Pinnacle Counseling has been serving the Rogers area for 15 plus years with client-centered approaches to anxiety, depression, marriage and family counseling, etc. Pinnacle Counseling counselors help their clients find empowerment and clarity to achieve their wellness goals. 

479.282.2443

6. Oaks Counseling

6815 Isaac's Orchard Rd, Springdale

Oaks Counseling is a group of trained and certified counselors with decades of combined experience who are fully equipped to help you process whatever it is you need to move toward a healthier life. 

7. Professional Counseling Services of NWA

6801 Isaac's Orchard Rd, Springdale

Professional Counseling Services of NWA specialize in individual counseling, stress management, clinical hypnosis, and professional life coaching. At Professional Counseling Services of NWA, you are the expert of your own life, collaborating with an expert in counseling to find solution-focused, individualized goals and treatments for your issues. 

479.799.5577

8. Brookway Counseling

801 Carlton St, Springdale

Brookway Counseling has a team of qualified and experienced counselors specializing in depression and anxiety counseling, ADHD, EMDR therapy, Christian counseling, psychological testing, eating disorders, marriage and family counseling, and online teletherapy.

479.255.5414

9. NWA Premier Therapy

2103 S 54th St, Rogers

NWA Premier Therapy specializes in trauma-focused counseling, though they also offer play therapy, therapy for those struggling with HSP issues, therapy for LGBTQIA+ individuals, grief counseling, and much more.

479.372.7446

479.389.8188 (text)

Photo courtesy of SHVETS

10. Fresh Roots Counseling

3901 W Financial Pkwy, Rogers

Fresh Roots Family Counseling has been serving the NWA community since 1995. They have a team of 20+ licensed professional counselors specializing in many therapy areas. Some techniques that make Fresh Roots stand out are Emotion-Focused couples therapy, EMDR, play therapy, co-parenting counseling, and Sexual Addiction Therapy.

479.986.8655

11. Bentonville Counseling Collective

2104 SE 14th St, Bentonville

Bentonville Counseling Collective offers counseling services to all those wanting to make a positive change in their lives. They specialize in relationship counseling, gender transition counseling, expressive arts therapy, therapy for therapists, telehealth video counseling, and trauma-informed therapy.

479.310.6850

12. Creative Counseling Center

902 McClain Rd, Bentonville

The counselors of the Creative Counseling Center of NWA have created a space of casual, confidential, and collaborative conversation to aid you on your healing journey. They offer services to individuals and couples for a wide variety of issues. 

479.364.0075

13. Soul Talk Therapy

900 SE 5th St, Bentonville

Soul Talk Therapy is in a quaint, comfortable space with dedicated counselors cultivating safe environments to explore thoughts, feelings, and experiences without any threat of judgment. 

479.888.5546

Photo courtesy of Alex Green

If you're still looking to find free and affordable counseling near you, or you want to learn more about what is available, check out opencounseling.com. For tips on how to find a counselor fit for you in NWA, read this blog post from Fresh Roots Family Counseling.

node.content:
There are very few people on the planet who do not stop and acknowledge an aircraft that passes by overhead. Even if it’s as brief a moment as one second, people notice and almost ubiquitously harbor some fascination with flying objects in the sky. 

Photo courtesy of Carol Zoch

It seems like such a distant place — the sky — but it really is more approachable than people realize. The Wright Brothers saw to that with their first flight in 1903. Aviation has come such a long way in just over a century, as now, flying is something anyone can do with training and help from local flight schools. 

Northwest Arkansas is slowly becoming one of the hottest spots for aviation in the United States – specifically recreational aviation, because of its accessibility and the ideal environment that this part of the country provides. Recreational aviation, or backcountry aviation, has put NWA and the Ozarks on the map for many pilots, almost exclusively due to the initiative at Fly Oz, the region’s recreational aviation arm based in Bentonville. 

Photo courtesy of Fly Oz 

Fly Oz and aviation enthusiasts in this part of the country have worked with private land owners to connect pilots and non-pilots to activities and experiences through a network of grass airstrips on land otherwise unreachable. Director of Fly Oz, Chip Gibbons, said people who come to fly in NWA have a bigger picture of the region than those who come mountain bike in the area for a week, which makes sense. Through initiatives to get people in the air and to different parts of the region and state, NWA has become a base in a network of adventure. 

“Here, our focus has really been on what you do once you have arrived,” Gibbons said. “Get out of the airplane, take in the scenery, do some fishing, do some paddling, you know, whatever lights you up.” 

Flying in and out of the backcountry is what the region is primarily known for in the world of aviation, but it also has the ideal infrastructure for learning to fly at any level and in any air space. Due to the lower density altitude here allowing airplanes to perform better, and the local flight schools being some of the most resourceful and approachable around, there aren’t many places better than NWA to learn to fly for fun.

“It’s almost the perfect little environment to do this in,” Gibbons said. “I don’t know what I would change about where we live that would make it better.” 

The two leading flight schools in the area are Summit Aviation in Bentonville and ARH Aviation in Springdale. Summit Aviation is the fixed-based operator at Thaden Field, a municipal and private jet airport in downtown Bentonville. ARH Aviation is a premier aviation supplier located at the Springdale municipal general aviation airport. Whether you train through Summit Aviation, participate in its OZ1 Flying Club department or learn to fly with experts at ARH Aviation, the sky is yours to conquer. Our region is yours to behold like never before. 

Photo courtesy of Carol Zoch

Chad Cox, the president of Summit Aviation, told Talk Business & Politics that Flying in NWA “isn’t just about getting from Point A to Point B.” It’s also about connecting to what’s happening in all the areas of recreation and leisure in NWA, adding to the overall adventure. 

Fly Oz and Fly AHR offer discovery flights and charter flights of different kinds for you to see and explore the beauty of our region in a whole new way. The scenic flights are also perfect for trying out how it feels to be in the sky. Like so many in recent years, who knows, you might immediately decide that becoming a pilot is for you. 

Becoming a private pilot through Summit Aviation in Bentonville or ARH Aviation in Springdale costs in the ballpark of $10,000 after you purchase course materials, pay for exam fees, aircraft rental, and ground and air instruction. Though it’s a bit pricey, there are scholarships out there to help. 

Whether you have a desire to become a pilot or not, there is a whole perspective of our region from the sky just waiting for you. So go check it out, and you won’t be disappointed. 

For more information about Fly Oz, click HERE. 

For more information about OZ1, click HERE. 

For more information about flight training through Summit Aviation, click HERE. 

For more information about flight training through ARH Aviation, click HERE.

The Jones Center is another one of those special amenities in Northwest Arkansas that if you don’t know about it, you should. The center is 220.000 square feet of space, deemed as a destination for growth. Bernice Jones, a driving force in the region, gifted the center to Springdale 25 years ago with the promise that “All are welcome.” 

 

The center is a recreation, education, and event center founded with a mission to strengthen and enrich the community, celebrate culture, and be a conduit for service and thriving collaboration. The vision for The Jones Center has always been that the community would be a part of it and make it their own. And with people doing just that, the center is continuously growing and adapting to the ever-changing region. 

 

The Jones Center and its 52-acre campus are currently in a phase of re-imagining. A project is brewing to “elevate The Jones Center’s core indoor recreation amenities with sustainability in mind while complimenting and blending with the Springdale Downtown Revitalization Master Plan.” 


﻿

 

Right now, the Jones Campus includes The Jones Center and the Center for Non-Profit @ the JTL Shops. The Jones Center has amenities such as an ice arena, pools, fitness center, gymnasium, runway bike park, and more. The Non-Profit @ the JTL Shops is home to more than 40 nonprofit organizations serving NWA, professional office and meeting space, and the Harvey Jones Education Building. 


 

The vision for the campus consists of bold changes that include introducing new open spaces and plazas, incorporating art pieces that pique interest and act as culturally inspired place-makers, and creating an interconnected system of hard and soft surface trails that tie The Jones Campus to downtown and beyond. The vision has a multi-layered approach with theme-based programming. The themes are wellness and recreation, gardens and ecology, community and gathering, arts and culture, and campus support. 


 

The project’s goals include creating another destination in NWA where people gather, “recreate, celebrate, and build a stronger sense of community,” expanding on Bernice’s ethos of welcoming all. The design elements of the project include the Meto Spine, Emma Ave. Connector + JTL Courtyard, The Community Common, OZ Play Area, Fitness Pad, OZ Gardens + Expanded Action Sports, and Woven Links + Patchwork Parking + JTL Plaza. 

 

Click HERE to learn all about it.
node.title: The Jones Campus: A Campus Adapting With A Continued Vision For Welcoming All

The City of Fayetteville is a world leader in the efforts of environmental sustainability, and the latest 50-acre park project downtown is no exception to the city’s goals. Construction on the Cultural Arts Corridor or, The Ramble, is currently underway with efforts to advance the city’s ecological and elemental care with sustainable means and ends, said Peter Nierengarten, the City’s Environmental Director and The Ramble’s project manager. The Ramble will be the city’s first large urban park, and though it will be similar to other parks in the U.S., The Ramble will stand out as a result of its attention to the surrounding environment. 

“It’s got a really strong focus on sustainability, low impact development, stormwater, and native ecology,” Nierengarten said. “And I think that will set it apart.”The Ramble will be the first in Arkansas to be a certified SITES project. The certification, according to The Sustainable SITES Initiative, determines that a landscape project helps “reduce water demand, filter and reduce stormwater runoff, provide wildlife habitat, reduce energy consumption, improve air quality, improve human health, and increase outdoor recreation opportunities.” 

The Ramble will check all of these boxes and more as it moves along toward completion. The new outdoor public space will not only provide spaces for native plant species and stormwater storage, but it will provide opportunities for anyone and everyone who wants to come and celebrate arts and culture or enjoy recreational activities or events. Nierengarten said, The Ramble will be a flexible space for programming that could be used for anything from small-scale events to a 2,500+ person festival. 

“The park will have space for downtown events including concerts and performances or festivals, starts and finishes for bicycle and running races, and everything in between,” Nierengarten said, “including when it’s not a programmed activity.”

The primary elements of The Ramble are the Fay Jones Woods, the Razorback Greenway, new streetscapes on West Avenue, a new parking deck on the corner of West and Dickson streets, and a new Civic Space on West Avenue. 

﻿

The improvements to the Fay Jones Woods will include the restoration of Tanglewood Branch Creek, which will be accessible to the public, providing a spot for cooling off in the hot summer months. There will also be new trails in the forest, gathering spaces, informal paths, and a boardwalk. The West Avenue Civic Plaza will feature a central lawn, promenade, art gardens, trails, and two buildings on the north and south ends that will be developed through public-private partnerships. Houses Inc. in Fayetteville has proposed one of the buildings be a four-story Food Hall. 

According to a press release, The Ramble’s name references “a full embrace of the journey” and incorporates the ideas behind the cadence of a directionless walk or bike ride, or a spontaneous conversation. The name also nods to an Arkansas-born musician and actor who hosted Midnight Ramble sessions in a barn on his property in Woodstock, New York, until his death in 2012.  

The Ramble is a project made possible by the Walton Family Foundation’s Design Excellence Program (DEP), which promotes high-level design in NWA. Nierengarten said all the DEP projects will complement each other, but The Ramble will “be an experience unlike anything else in Northwest Arkansas, from my perspective.” 

The Ramble is on track to be complete by March 2024. To see more about The Ramble and the timeline of the project, click HERE or see below.
node.title: Fayetteville’s To Be Largest City Park Promises Sustainability And Opportunity

INTERFORM’s 2022 Northwest Arkansas Fashion Week (NWAFW) came to a close this last Saturday resulting in the best season it’s ever had, according to INTERFORM CEO Robin Atkinson. NWAFW’s return to a live and in-person show after two years only generated bigger and better successes with intentional and inspired themes, such as identity and comfortability. 

AS NWAFW is all about incubating talent and uplifting community, the runway represented designers from the Marshallese and Congolese communities, and people of all kinds were models for the show. INTERFORM’s communications manager Rochelle Bailey said part of the organization’s mission is to “show the community back to itself” and exhibit representation. 

Along with the strides in diversity, inclusivity, and education, NWA is making pace with its connectedness to cities of resource as well. The CEO of the New York’s Council of Fashion Designers of America was present at this year’s NWAFW, and Atkinson said it’s relationships like this that create exchange and visibility between NWA and coastal influences. 

Saturday’s New York based headliner Rinat Brodach said this year’s show was somewhat of a renaissance after the pandemic as designers explore how to use clothing as tools for social change, which is exactly what INTERFORM is about. 

“My clothes are beyond clothing,” Brodach said. “They’re tools of self-expression.” 

Photos by Gael Langdon with NWA Daily
